instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SSD, Need advice!
threads.message:
I need some logic board repair advice, I am repairing an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that showed no ssd (soldered to board), and I ended up finding what the problem was, some liquid got on <CAPACITOR>C8784</CAPACITOR> and removed the <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD_FMC</SIGNAL> pad (pad 1). I looked up the capacitor in the schematic PDF file and it shares <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD_FMC</SIGNAL> with <CAPACITOR>C8783</CAPACITOR>, 82, 81, 80. If I ran a wire from <CAPACITOR>C8782</CAPACITOR> to <CAPACITOR>C8784</CAPACITOR>, would this complete the circuit? Correct me if im wrong

I provided photos too

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SSD, Need advice!
threads.message:
Missing 1uF filter cap is not critical.
But you must check to have continuity on other componentts placed in the same power rail; as is possible to have corroded trace, inside the board.
Check for example from <CAPACITOR>C8781</CAPACITOR> to <CAPACITOR>C8782</CAPACITOR>, small resistors, etc...
